0: A quick-thinking bus driver has been praised after he manoeuvred his double-decker alongside a burning building to allow a man to escape a serious house fire. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The naked victim was able to leap from a second floor window onto the bus’ roof after Andy Waterman, the 48-year-old driver, pulled up alongside. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Waterman was heading to his depot in Braintree, Essex, when a group of people in the road alerted him to the blaze. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man in the flat, who was naked because he was in the shower when the fire started, jumped 10ft onto the bus roof. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Waterman then slowly drove away with the man balanced on top of his vehicle, which was out of service at the time and had no passengers aboard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR When they were at a safe distance, firefighters were able to put up a ladder to rescue the man, in his 40s, who was later treated for smoke inhalation. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Waterman, of West Mersea, Essex, said: "The police told me that I did a good job. It wasn't until I got home that someone said that I had saved a life. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I have been driving buses for eight years and nothing like this has happened before. I am just pleased the man is alive." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Describing his role in the drama, he said: "A group of people started flagging me down and they were asking me to stop. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I drove nearer and all I could see was thick, black smoke. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We lined the bus up, close to the building to enable him to jump from the flat roof on to the top of the bus - he had no other exit. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The poor guy was in the shower - he was completely naked. It was freezing cold.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A spokesman for Essex Fire and Rescue said: "Without the quick-thinking of Mr Waterman this incident could have had a very different outcome and the man who managed to get onto the roof could well have lost his life."
